problem.name: Minesweeper I
problem.problemDescription: A mine sweeper being developed by the US Navy uses a Magnesium DiBoride superconducting magnet that must be cooled to 25 K in order to operate reliably. Power constraints on the ship limit the power consumed by the cryocooler to less than 20 kW. The 0.5 m diameter by 1.0 m tall magnet that weighs 2,500 kg is to be mounted on a support cylinder inside a cylindrical vessel that has maximum inside dimensions of 0.6 m diameter by 1.5 m length. The flexible current leads that provide electric current to the magnet add a constant 50-watt heat load on the cryocooler. You may design the support system as though it were under a pure stress load, but you need to incorporate a factor of 10 to account for the fact that the support actually has square corners and another factor of 10 for design safety. Determine a low cost support system for the superconducting magnet. The navy is offering $10,000 for a valid solution to this problem.

problem.name: Minesweeper II
problem.problemDescription: A mine sweeper being developed by the US Navy uses a Magnesium DiBoride superconducting magnet that must be cooled to 100 K in order to operate reliably. Power constraints on the ship limit the power consumed by the cryocooler to less than 100 kW. The 0.5 m diameter by 1.0 m tall magnet that weighs 2,500 kg is to be mounted on a support cylinder inside a cylindrical vessel that has maximum inside dimensions of 0.6 m diameter by 3 m length. You can ignore the heat load caused by the flexible current leads that provide electric current to the magnet. You may design the support system as though it were under a pure stress load, but you need to incorporate a factor of 10 to account for the fact that the support actually has square corners and another factor of 10 for design safety. Determine a low cost support system for the superconducting magnet. The navy is offering $5,000 for a valid solution to this problem.

problem.name: Minesweeper III
problem.problemDescription: A mine sweeper being developed by the US Navy uses a Magnesium DiBoride superconducting magnet that must be cooled to 20 K in order to operate reliably. Power constraints on the ship limit the power consumed by the cryocooler to less than 20 kW. The 0.5 m diameter by 1.0 m tall magnet that weighs 5,000 kg is to be mounted on 6 identical support posts inside a cylindrical vessel that has maximum inside dimensions of 0.6 m diameter by 1.5 m length. The flexible current leads that provide electric current to the magnet add a constant 50-watt heat load on the cryocooler. You may design the support system as though it were under a pure stress load, but you need to incorporate a factor of 10 to account for the fact that the support actually has square corners and another factor of 10 for design safety. Determine a low cost support system for the superconducting magnet. The navy is offering $15,000 for a valid soultion to this problem.

problem.name: Space Depot (hydrogen)
problem.problemDescription: NASA is developing a space cryogen depot for travel to Mars. Zero boil off dewars are a critical component in NASA's plans for a space cryogen depot. A zero-boil-off dewar is one for which a cryocooler intercepts the heat leak to the inner vessel so that no liquid cryogen boils away. As shown on the design board, a set of 8 identical straps is used to support the inner vessel of the dewar inside its vacuum shell. The liquid cryogen plus the inner vessel have a combined mass of 6,500kg. You must allow for a 4g acceleration during lift-off and a factor of 10 for design safety. Determine appropriate straps (geometry and material) so that the dewar can be used to store liquid hydrogen at its normal boiling point of 20.3 K indefinitely. Note that due to the limitations of power generation in space, you must limit your cryocooler's input power to 4125 Watts.

problem.name: Space Depot (oxygen)
problem.problemDescription: NASA is developing a space cryogen depot for travel to Mars. Zero boil off dewars are a critical component in NASA's plans for a space cryogen depot. A zero-boil-off dewar is one for which a cryocooler intercepts the heat leak to the inner vessel so that no liquid cryogen boils away. As shown on the design board, a set of 8 identical straps is used to support the inner vessel of the dewar inside its vacuum shell. The liquid cryogen plus the inner vessel have a combined mass of 2900 kg. You must allow for a 4g acceleration during lift-off and a factor of 10 for design safety. Determine appropriate straps (geometry and material) so that the dewar can be used to store liquid oxygen at its normal boiling point of 90.2 K indefinitely. Note that due to the limitations of power generation in space, you must limit your cryocooler's input power to 800 Watts.

problem.name: Space Depot (methane)
problem.problemDescription: NASA is developing a space cryogen depot for travel to Mars. Zero boil off dewars are a critical component in NASA's plans for a space cryogen depot. A zero-boil-off dewar is one for which a cryocooler intercepts the heat leak to the inner vessel so that no liquid cryogen boils away. As shown on the design board, a set of 8 identical straps is used to support the inner vessel of the dewar inside its vacuum shell. The liquid cryogen plus the inner vessel have a combined mass of 2600 kg. You must allow for a 4g acceleration during lift-off and a factor of 10 for design safety. Determine appropriate straps (geometry and material) so that the dewar can be used to store liquid methane at its normal boiling point of 112 K indefinitely. Note that due to the limitations of power generation in space, you must limit your cryocooler's input power to 500 Watts.
